properties.name: Low Sodium
properties.description: Aim for no more than 2,300 mg of sodium a day. Your health care provider may suggest you aim for a smaller amount if you have high blood pressure. Src - https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diabetes/in-depth/diabetes-diet/art-20044295

properties.name: Refined Carbohydrate
properties.description:
Certain types of refined, processed carbohydrates, like white bread, pasta, juice, sweets, cake, and candy, can increase blood sugars rapidly. In addition, they contain very little nutrition and are rich in calories that can cause weight gain. 
                    Source:https://www.verywellhealth.com/type-2-diabetes-nutrition-and-weight-loss-4014311#:~:text=Limit%20Certain%20Types%20of%20Food&text=Certain%20types%20of%20refined%2C%20processed,that%20can%20cause%20weight%20gain.

properties.name: Heart Healthy Items
properties.description: Omega-3 fatty acids are considered food for heart health. Source: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Omega3FattyAcids-HealthProfessional/. As diabetes is associated with heart disease (source:https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/diabetes-complications/diabetes-and-your-heart.html#:~:text=People%20with%20diabetes%20are%20at,your%20risk%20for%20heart%20disease.), omega-3 fatty acids are recommended my MayoClinic for diabetes.

properties.name: Animal Protein
properties.description: MayoClinic suggests even if you choose lean or extra-lean cuts of beef, don't eat too much. The Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommends that adults eat no more than a total of 26 ounces of meat, poultry and eggs per week. One portion of cooked meat is three ounces. That's about the size of a deck of cards. Read more - https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/nutrition-and-healthy-eating/in-depth/cuts-of-beef/art-20043833

properties.name: Medium Fat
properties.description:
This food item has medium fat and recommended with caution. Due to increased association with heart disease, high fat items are suggested to be avoided for diabetes as well. Source:https://www.healthline.com/health/diabetes/how-much-fat-can-a-diabetic-have-a-day#nutrition-labels
                    The amount of fat considered to be high, medium and low can be found at - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/food-types/different-fats-nutrition/

properties.name: Low Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat less 5g per 100g portion size is considered as low saturated fat. Though these food items have low saturated fat, it is suggested to have it with caution
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: Good Fats
properties.description: Foods that contain Polyunsatured fat and Monounsaturated fat are considered as good fat. Omega-3 and Omega-6 are polyunsaturated fat. Read more about subcategories on - https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Classification-of-fatty-acids-based-on-their-carbon-chain-length-and-their-number-of_fig3_321847709 or https://nutritionsource.hsph.harvard.edu/what-should-you-eat/fats-and-cholesterol/types-of-fat/

properties.name: Low Trans Fat
properties.description:
According to World Health Organization, one can consume only 2.2g of trans-fat per day. Read more on - https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/trans-fat
                    Converting, this is no more than 1% of calorie from trans-fat. These food items have less than 1% of calorie from trans fat. However, it is suggested to strictly monitor trans-fat intake eventhough it is within allowed limit.

properties.name: Low Sodium
properties.description: Aim for no more than 2,300 mg of sodium a day. Your health care provider may suggest you aim for a smaller amount if you have high blood pressure. Src - https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diabetes/in-depth/diabetes-diet/art-20044295

properties.name: Low Cholestrol
properties.description:
It is suggested that individuals with risk factors of heart disease should not have more than 200 milligrams of cholesterol per day (source: https://www.ucsfhealth.org/education/cholesterol-content-of-foods). 
                    These food items have low cholesterol as per nutrition content. However, it is suggested to have it with caution.

properties.name: Added Sugars
properties.description:
When it comes to fruit and diabetes, it's best to avoid fruit with added sugar. The most likely culprits for this 
                    are dried and canned fruit and fruit products like jams and jellies. The best way to know whether the fruit product contains added sugar 
                    is by looking at the ingredient label. Source:https://www.verywellhealth.com/type-2-diabetes-food-6744460

properties.name: Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat 5g per 100g portion size is considered as high saturated fat. 
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: High Fats
properties.description:
Due to increased association with heart disease, high fat items are suggested to be avoided for diabetes as well. Source:https://www.healthline.com/health/diabetes/how-much-fat-can-a-diabetic-have-a-day#nutrition-labels
                    The amount of fat considered to be high, medium and low can be found at - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/food-types/different-fats-nutrition/

properties.name: Low Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat less 5g per 100g portion size is considered as low saturated fat. Though these food items have low saturated fat, it is suggested to have it with caution
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: Mixed Carbohydrate
properties.description: A few food items such as Pears and Apples may have high-fiber and high-sugars. Users with diabetes are advised to have it with caution. Source: https://diabetes.org/food-nutrition/understanding-carbs/get-to-know-carbs#:~:text=Pulses%20(like%20lentils%20and%20peas,wheat%2C%20wheat%20bran%20and%20oats

properties.name: Low Trans Fat
properties.description:
According to World Health Organization, one can consume only 2.2g of trans-fat per day. Read more on - https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/trans-fat
                    Converting, this is no more than 1% of calorie from trans-fat. These food items have less than 1% of calorie from trans fat. However, it is suggested to strictly monitor trans-fat intake eventhough it is within allowed limit.

properties.name: Added Sugars
properties.description:
When it comes to fruit and diabetes, it's best to avoid fruit with added sugar. The most likely culprits for this 
                    are dried and canned fruit and fruit products like jams and jellies. The best way to know whether the fruit product contains added sugar 
                    is by looking at the ingredient label. Source:https://www.verywellhealth.com/type-2-diabetes-food-6744460

properties.name: Heart Healthy Items
properties.description: Omega-3 fatty acids are considered food for heart health. Source: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Omega3FattyAcids-HealthProfessional/. As diabetes is associated with heart disease (source:https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/diabetes-complications/diabetes-and-your-heart.html#:~:text=People%20with%20diabetes%20are%20at,your%20risk%20for%20heart%20disease.), omega-3 fatty acids are recommended my MayoClinic for diabetes.

properties.name: Plant Protein
properties.description: These food item have protein source that are from plants or with absence of cholestrol. Read more on impact of plant based protein or protein without cholestrol here - https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/diet-eating-physical-activity

properties.name: Medium Fat
properties.description:
This food item has medium fat and recommended with caution. Due to increased association with heart disease, high fat items are suggested to be avoided for diabetes as well. Source:https://www.healthline.com/health/diabetes/how-much-fat-can-a-diabetic-have-a-day#nutrition-labels
                    The amount of fat considered to be high, medium and low can be found at - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/food-types/different-fats-nutrition/

properties.name: Low Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat less 5g per 100g portion size is considered as low saturated fat. Though these food items have low saturated fat, it is suggested to have it with caution
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: High Sodium
properties.description: Aim for no more than 2,300 mg of sodium a day. Your health care provider may suggest you aim for a smaller amount if you have high blood pressure. Src - https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diabetes/in-depth/diabetes-diet/art-20044295

properties.name: Good Fats
properties.description: Foods that contain Polyunsatured fat and Monounsaturated fat are considered as good fat. Omega-3 and Omega-6 are polyunsaturated fat. Read more about subcategories on - https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Classification-of-fatty-acids-based-on-their-carbon-chain-length-and-their-number-of_fig3_321847709 or https://nutritionsource.hsph.harvard.edu/what-should-you-eat/fats-and-cholesterol/types-of-fat/

properties.name: Low Trans Fat
properties.description:
According to World Health Organization, one can consume only 2.2g of trans-fat per day. Read more on - https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/trans-fat
                    Converting, this is no more than 1% of calorie from trans-fat. These food items have less than 1% of calorie from trans fat. However, it is suggested to strictly monitor trans-fat intake eventhough it is within allowed limit.

properties.name: Heart Healthy Items
properties.description: Omega-3 fatty acids are considered food for heart health. Source: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Omega3FattyAcids-HealthProfessional/. As diabetes is associated with heart disease (source:https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/diabetes-complications/diabetes-and-your-heart.html#:~:text=People%20with%20diabetes%20are%20at,your%20risk%20for%20heart%20disease.), omega-3 fatty acids are recommended my MayoClinic for diabetes.

properties.description: These food item have protein source that are from plants or with absence of cholestrol. Read more on impact of plant based protein or protein without cholestrol here - https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/diet-eating-physical-activity

properties.name: Low Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat less 5g per 100g portion size is considered as low saturated fat. Though these food items have low saturated fat, it is suggested to have it with caution
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: Good Fats
properties.description: Foods that contain Polyunsatured fat and Monounsaturated fat are considered as good fat. Omega-3 and Omega-6 are polyunsaturated fat. Read more about subcategories on - https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Classification-of-fatty-acids-based-on-their-carbon-chain-length-and-their-number-of_fig3_321847709 or https://nutritionsource.hsph.harvard.edu/what-should-you-eat/fats-and-cholesterol/types-of-fat/

properties.name: High Fats
properties.description:
Due to increased association with heart disease, high fat items are suggested to be avoided for diabetes as well. Source:https://www.healthline.com/health/diabetes/how-much-fat-can-a-diabetic-have-a-day#nutrition-labels
                    The amount of fat considered to be high, medium and low can be found at - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/food-types/different-fats-nutrition/

properties.name: Heart Healthy Items
properties.description: Omega-3 fatty acids are considered food for heart health. Source: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Omega3FattyAcids-HealthProfessional/. As diabetes is associated with heart disease (source:https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/diabetes-complications/diabetes-and-your-heart.html#:~:text=People%20with%20diabetes%20are%20at,your%20risk%20for%20heart%20disease.), omega-3 fatty acids are recommended my MayoClinic for diabetes.

properties.name: Plant Protein
properties.description: These food item have protein source that are from plants or with absence of cholestrol. Read more on impact of plant based protein or protein without cholestrol here - https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/diet-eating-physical-activity

properties.name: Medium Fat
properties.description:
This food item has medium fat and recommended with caution. Due to increased association with heart disease, high fat items are suggested to be avoided for diabetes as well. Source:https://www.healthline.com/health/diabetes/how-much-fat-can-a-diabetic-have-a-day#nutrition-labels
                    The amount of fat considered to be high, medium and low can be found at - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/food-types/different-fats-nutrition/

properties.name: Low Saturated Fats
properties.description:
Saturated fat appears to be associated with insulin resistance and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes 
                    (source: https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/diabetes/three-diet-changes-to-help-lose-weight-and-better-manage-your-type-2-diabetes/#:~:text=Saturated%20fat%20appears%20to%20be,Check%20food%20labels.) 
                    All the items with saturated fat less 5g per 100g portion size is considered as low saturated fat. Though these food items have low saturated fat, it is suggested to have it with caution
                    More on National Health Service from UK - https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/eat-well/how-to-eat-a-balanced-diet/eat-less-saturated-fat/#:~:text=Look%20out%20for%20%22saturates%22%20or,and%205g%20saturates%20per%20100g.

properties.name: Good Fats
properties.description: Foods that contain Polyunsatured fat and Monounsaturated fat are considered as good fat. Omega-3 and Omega-6 are polyunsaturated fat. Read more about subcategories on - https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Classification-of-fatty-acids-based-on-their-carbon-chain-length-and-their-number-of_fig3_321847709 or https://nutritionsource.hsph.harvard.edu/what-should-you-eat/fats-and-cholesterol/types-of-fat/

properties.name: Low Trans Fat
properties.description:
According to World Health Organization, one can consume only 2.2g of trans-fat per day. Read more on - https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/trans-fat
                    Converting, this is no more than 1% of calorie from trans-fat. These food items have less than 1% of calorie from trans fat. However, it is suggested to strictly monitor trans-fat intake eventhough it is within allowed limit.

properties.name: Low Sodium
properties.description: Aim for no more than 2,300 mg of sodium a day. Your health care provider may suggest you aim for a smaller amount if you have high blood pressure. Src - https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diabetes/in-depth/diabetes-diet/art-20044295

properties.allowed: high: more than 17.5g; medium: 3 to 17.5g; low: less than 3g, fat-free: less than 0.5g
Anything with 10% to 35% - good protein. More than 35% - high protein
properties.explanation:
